revision.comment: copied my RSI article from wikipedia, will work to clean up at a later date.
revision.text:
[[Image:Intubation endotracheal tube laryngoscope.jpg|left|250px|thumb|Placement of endotracheal tube with a laryngoscope]] Endotracheal intubation describes the technique of passing a tube through the vocal cords. A cuff is then usually inflated to provide a seal allowing positive pressure ventilation, and to protect the airway from the aspiration of gastric contents or upper airway material.
Indications for endotracheal tube (ETT) placement include: severe hypoxaemia requiring PEEP; hypercapnia with acidosis; inability to protect the airway; to control ventilation in the presence of raised intracranial (or intraocular) pressure; to facilitate certain diagnostic or therapeutic procedures; to allow administration of neuromuscular blockade
Endotracheal placement is a painful and stimulating procedure and requires induction of anaesthesia and muscular relaxation for facilitation. In cooperative patients topical anaesthesia alone can be used.
The classical technique in a starved patient undergoing elective anaesthesia describes the administraion of a hypnotic (sleep inducing) drug, gentle ventilation to check for airway patency, followed by administration of a muscle relaxant. A rapid onset opiate may also be administered to blunt sympathetic response to intubation. The vocal cords are then visualised with the aid of a laryngoscope and the endotracheal tube visualised passing through them. Confirmation of endotracheal placement is sought by 3-point ausculation (both lung fields and the stomach), and capnography. The optimum position for endotracheal intubation is described as 'sniffing the morning air'. This aligns the axes of the oral cavity, pharynx and trachea. The neck is flexed (on a pillow) and the head extended. When intubating it is important not to push the laryngoscope against the persons teeth which could cause discomfort or dental deformations, and can lead to malpractice.
In the practice of emergency medicine, ideal intubating conditions as described above are rare. Patients are almost always unstarved or have other factors which may contribute to delayed gastric emptying. Additionally many patients are unstable or hypoxaemic. A technique known as 'rapid-sequence induction' is often used.
'''Rapid Sequence Induction'''
Here the step of checking airway patency prior to administration of muscle relaxation is omitted with the aim of securing the airway as quickly as possible. A pre-calculated dose of hypnotic, followed immediately by a rapidly aciting muscle relaxant, are administered. Cricoid pressure by a trained assistant is applied. As soon as adequate intubation conditions are deemed to have been obtained, direct laryngoscopy followed by endotracheal intubation is performed. In patients with suspected cervical spine injury, patients are generally removed from their hard-collars just prior to induction, and the spine is immobilised by manual in-line stabilisation. This can impair the view of the larynx with conventional laryngoscopy.
Because the ability to ventilate prior to administration of muscle is not determined, the 'can't intubate, can't ventilate' scenario is always possible. This represents an immediate threat to life, and it is important that one is familiar with a 'failed intubation drill'.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]
==Rapid Sequence Induction Technique== Rapid sequence intubation refers to the pharmacologically induced [[sedation]] and [[neuromuscular paralysis]] prior to intubation of the trachea. The technique is a quicker form of the process normally used to induce [[general anesthesia]]. A useful framework for describing the technique of RSI is the "seven Ps"<ref>{{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Angus|title=Rapid Sequence Intubation - A guide for assistants|url=http://www.scottishintensivecare.org.uk/education/RSI%20brochure.pdf|work=Scottish Intensive Care Society Education|publisher=NHS - Education for Scotland|accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref>.
=== Preparation === The patient is assessed to predict the difficulty of intubation. Continuous physiological monitoring such as [[Electrocardiogram||ECG]] and [[pulse oximetry]] is put on the patient. The equipment and drugs for the intubation are planned, including the endotracheal tube size, the laryngoscope size, and drug dosage. Drugs are prepared in syringes. [[Intravenous]] access is obtained to deliver the drugs, usually by placing one or two IV [[cannulae]].
===Preoxygenation=== The aim of preoxygenation is to replace the nitrogen that forms the majority of the [[Functional residual capacity|functional residual capacity]] with oxygen. This provides an oxygen reservoir that will delay the depletion of oxygen in the absence of ventilation (after paralysis) for up to 8 minutes (to an oxygen saturation of 90%) in the healthy adult<ref>{{cite pmid|9357902}}</ref>. This time will be significantly reduced in obese patients, ill patients and children. Preoxygenation is usually performed by giving 100% oxygen via a tightly fitting face mask.
===Pretreatment=== Pretreatment consists of the medications given to specific groups of high-risk patients 3 minutes before the paralysis stage with the aim of protecting the patient from the adverse effects of introducing the laryngoscope and endotracheal tube. Intubation causes increased [[Sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] activity, an increase in [[intracranial pressure]] and bronchospasm. Patients with [[Reactive airway disease|reactive airway disease]], increased intracranial pressure, or cardiovascular disease may benefit from pretreatment.
===Paralysis with induction=== With standard intravenous induction of general anesthesia, the patient typically receives an [[opioid]], and then a hypnotic medication. Generally the patient will be manually ventilated for a short period of time before a [[neuromuscular block]]ing agent is administered and the patient is intubated. During rapid sequence induction, the person still receives an IV opioid. However, the difference lies in the fact that the induction drug and neuromuscular blocking agent are administered in rapid succession with no time allowed for manual ventilation.
Commonly used hypnotics include [[Sodium thiopental|thiopental]], [[propofol]] and [[etomidate]]. Commonly used neuromuscular blocking agents used include [[Suxamethonium chloride|succinylcholine]] and [[Rocuronium bromide|rocuronium]].<ref name=Pousman2000>{{cite journal|last=Pousman|first=RM|title=Rapid Sequence Induction for Prehospital Providers|journal=The Internet Journal of Emergency and Intensive Care Medicine|volume=4|issue=1|pages=|year=2000|pmid=|pmc=|doi=|url=http://www.ispub.com/ostia/index.php?xmlFilePath=journals/ijeicm/vol4n1/rapid.xml#documentHeading-VI.Pharmacology}}</ref> The [[Neuromuscular-blocking drug|neuromuscular blocking agents]] paralyze all of the [[Skeletal striated muscle|skeletal muscles]], most notably and importantly in the [[oropharynx]], [[larynx]], and [[Thoracic diaphragm|diaphragm]]. [[Opioid]]s such as [[fentanyl]] may be given to attenuate the responses to the intubation process ([[tachycardia|accelerated heart rate]] and increased [[intracranial pressure]]). This is supposed to have advantages in patients with [[Ischaemic heart disease|ischemic heart disease]] and those with [[brain injury]] (e.g. after [[traumatic brain injury]] or [[stroke]]). [[Lidocaine]] is also theorized to blunt a rise in intracranial pressure during laryngoscopy, although this remains controversial and its use varies greatly. Atropine may be used to prevent a reflex bradycardia from vagal stimulation during laryngoscopy, especially in young children and infants. Despite their common use, such adjunctive medications have not been demonstrated to improve outcomes.<ref name=Neilipovitz2007>{{cite journal|last=Neilipovitz|first=DT|last2=Crosby|first2=ET|title=No evidence for decreased incidence of aspiration after rapid sequence intubation|journal=Canadian Journal of Anesthesia|volume=54|issue=9|pages=748–64|year=2007|pmid=17766743|pmc=|doi=10.1007/BF03026872|url=http://www.cja-jca.org/cgi/content/full/54/9/748}}</ref>
===Positioning=== This phase consists of appropriately positioning the patient to facilitate intubation. The optimal position to open up the airway is usually described as a "sniffing" position, with head extension and flexion of the neck on the body. This is usually done by placing a pillow under the head of the patient and extending the head. However, some evidence exists that head extension alone results in similar ease of intubation<ref>{{cite pmid|11605921}}</ref>.
Sellick's maneuver, or cricothyroid pressure, may also be used in this phase.
===Placement of tube=== During this stage, [[laryngoscopy]] is performed to visualize the [[glottis]]. The endotracheal tube is then passed in between the [[Vocal folds|vocal cords]], and a cuff is inflated around the tube to hold it in place and prevent aspiration of stomach contents.
The position of the tube in the trachea can be confirmed in a number of ways, including observing increasing end tidal carbon dioxide, aspiration, chest movement and misting of the tube.
===Postintubation management=== Malpositioning of the endotracheal tube (in a bronchus, above the glottis, or in the oesophagus) should be excluded by performing a chest [[X-ray]].

=Ngithanda ukudlala ibhola=
In this lesson, we learn how to express likes and dislikes. To this end, we introduce and explain how to use infinitives e.g. 'to play'. A number of verbs are also introduced.
==Umbhuti usebenzela i-Eskom==
:'''uNandi''': Sawubona Philani! :'''uPhilani''': Yebo sawubona Nandi! :'''uNandi''': Unjani? :'''uPhilani''': Ngisaphila, wena unjani? :'''uNandi''': Nami ngiyaphila. :'''uPhilani''': Unombhuthi angithi? :'''uNandi''': Yebo, nginombhuthi. :'''uPhilani''': Umbhuthi usebenzaphi? :'''uNandi''': Umbhuthi usebenzela i-Eskom. :'''uPhilani''': Eish, yena uyasebenza kakhulu angithi? :'''uNandi''': Yebo, manje uyasebenza kakhulu. Wena unombhuti? :'''uPhilani''': Cha, anginambhuti. :'''uNandi''': Hamba kahle. :'''uPhilani''': Sala kahle.
{| border=1 class="wikitable" ! '''Zulu''' ! '''English''' |- | angithi | isn't it |- | anginambhuti | I do not have a brother |- | Eish | wow |- | sebenzela | work for |}
When "na" is used in the negative, we just drop the first letter of the noun then add the na. So, to say I do have not a sister: Angi+na+sisi becomes 'Anginasisi'. We have also introduced the word angithi, which also be used instead of na or intonation.
==Ngithanda ubisi noshizi==
'''Funda'''
''Sanibona! NginguThatho wakwaNdlovu. Ngineminyaka engu-21 ubudala. Ngingumfundi. Ngifunda eWits. Ngifunda ukuba i-Accountant. Ngineminyaka engu-3 ngifunda. Ngiyafunda kakhulu kodwa ngithanda ukudlala ibhola. Ngiphuza ubhiya newayini kodwa ngithanda ubisi noshizi futhi. Ngiyajabula ukunazi!''
{| border=1 class="wikitable" ! '''Zulu''' ! '''English''' |- | umfundi | student |- | iWits | Wits (University of the Witwatersrand) |- | ukuba | to be |- | thanda | like |- | dlala | play |- | ibhola | soccer/ ball |- | phuza | drink |- |ubhiya | beer |- | iwayini | wine |- | ubisi | milk |- | ushizi | cheese |}
Notice the use of uku- as a prefix, it means 'to' so if we want to say I like to play, for instance, we simply put uku- onto the second verb as its prefix 'Ngithanda ukudlala'. Also notice the use of na-, it links two nouns with coalescence - merging - and means either 'with' or 'and'.
In the above table, we have introduced additional nouns. The nouns beginning with u- below to class 1a and those with i- to class 3. At this stage, you should be able to understand the whole passage.
==Negation==
'''Funda'''
''Ugogo wami akathandi ukubhema. Yena akathandi ikofi newayini. Akaphuzi ubisi kodwa ngidla ushizi. Akadli utamatisi. Ngiphuza ubisi namanzi kodwa angiphuzi ubiya. Obhuti bathanda ukuphuzi mqombothi. Abaphuzi iwayini.''
{| border=1 class="wikitable" ! '''Zulu''' ! '''English''' |- | bhema | smoke |- | amanzi | water |- | umqombothi | traditional beer |}
The passage above illustrates how to form negatives in the present tense. We add an 'a' before the subject concord and change the final letter of the verb to an 'i'. But this still raises questions, what happens when the first letter of the subject concord is a 'u'? Well in that case, it becomes a little more complicated. The table below show a summary of what happens.
{| border=1 class="wikitable" ! What happens with u ! |- | Mina angiphuzi ijusi. | Thina asiphuzi ijusi. |- | Wena awuphuzi ubisi. | Nina aniphuzi ubisi. |- | Yena akadli ushizi. | Bona abadli ushizi. |- | Ugogo akaphuzi iwayini. | Ogogo abaphuzi ibiya. |- | Umzali akaphuzi amanzi | Abazali abaphuzi amanzi. |- | iKholigi alidli ushizi. | amaKholigi awadli ushizi. |}
==Summary==
* We can say that we don't have a family member or an object. ''Anginagogo. '' * We can say what we like and dislike. ''Ngithanda/angithandi'' * We can tell people what we like to do and what don't like to do. ''Ngithanda ukudlala/ Angithandi ukudlala.'' * We have learnt how to negate verbs in the present. ''Akathandi ubisi. Awuthandi ushizi.''

revision.comment: /* Proof by Shilov (1969) */ changed to direct proof
revision.text:
==Lemma for the eigenspace== All eigenvectors of the linear transformation ''A'' that correspond to the eigenvalue λ form a subspace ''L''<sup>(λ)</sup> in ''L''. ===Proof by Shilov (1969)=== In fact, if ''Ax''<sub>1</sub> = λ''x''<sub>1</sub>, and ''Ax''<sub>2</sub> = λ''x''<sub>2</sub>, then :''A''(α''x''<sub>1</sub> + β''x''<sub>2</sub>) = α''Ax''<sub>1</sub> + β''Ax''<sub>2</sub> = αλ''x''<sub>1</sub> + βλ''x''<sub>2</sub> = λ (α''x''<sub>1</sub> + β''x''<sub>2</sub>) with which the statement in the lemma is proven.
==Lemma for linear independence of eigenvectors== Eigenvectors ''x''<sub>1</sub>, ''x''<sub>2</sub>, ... , ''x''<sub>''n''</sub> of the (linear) transformation ''A'' with respective pairwise distinct eigenvalues λ<sub>1</sub>, λ<sub>2</sub>, ... , λ<sub>''n''</sub>, are linearly independent. ===Proof by Shilov (1969)=== This statement is proved by induction to number ''n''. It is obvious that for ''n'' = 1 the lemma is true. Suppose that the lemma is true for all ''n'' – 1 eigenvalues of the transformation ''A''; it remains to show that it is true for all ''n'' eigenvectors of the transformation ''A''. Suppose a linear combination of ''n'' eigenvectors of the transformation ''A'' is 0: :α<sub>1</sub>''x''<sub>1</sub> + α<sub>2</sub>''x''<sub>2</sub> + ... + α<sub>''n''</sub>''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = 0.
Applying transformation ''A'' to this identity, one has :α<sub>1</sub>λ<sub>1</sub>''x''<sub>1</sub> + α<sub>2</sub>λ<sub>2</sub>''x''<sub>2</sub> + ... + α<sub>''n''</sub>λ<sub>''n''</sub>''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = 0. Multiply the first equation by λ<sub>''n''</sub> and subtract from the second one; one obtains :α<sub>1</sub>(λ<sub>1</sub> – λ<sub>''n''</sub>)''x''<sub>1</sub> + α<sub>2</sub>(λ<sub>2</sub> – λ<sub>''n''</sub>)''x''<sub>2</sub> + ... + α<sub>''n'' – 1</sub>(λ<sub>''n'' – 1</sub> – λ<sub>''n''</sub>)''x''<sub>''n'' – 1</sub> = 0, from where by induction all coefficients must be zero. Distinct eigenvalues have nonzero difference, so each α<sub>i</sub> = 0 for ''i'' < ''n''; the first equation reduces to :α<sub>''n''</sub>''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = 0 which means α<sub>''n''</sub> = 0, too. Consequently, all coefficients α<sub>i</sub> are 0. Therefore, the vectors ''x''<sub>1</sub>, ''x''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''x<sub>n</sub>'' are linearly independent.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: moved [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion/Advanced Network Administration & Management Course]] to [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Advanced Network Administration & Management Course]]: Per [[Wikibooks_talk:Votes_for_deletion#Page_rename_proposal]]
revision.text: == [[Advanced Network Administration & Management Course]] == {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand nuvola.svg|30px]] | Closed as '''delete'''. [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 04:41, 12 February 2008 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | High-level contents-only stub since February 2007. [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 01:37, 2 February 2008 (UTC) *{{vd}} I would prefer not to call this a "stub" as these seem to have a value. This does not. It is barely even an outline and as it was "work in progress" a year ago I feel we must conclude it is abandoned --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 08:01, 2 February 2008 (UTC) *:I would have deleted it on the spot, but I know how some people feel about "stubs" so I thought I should at least ask first :-) [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 01:44, 3 February 2008 (UTC) *{{vd}} - per nom and Herby. --- [[User:Anonymous Dissident|Anonymous Dissident]][[User_talk:Anonymous Dissident|Talk]] 11:01, 2 February 2008 (UTC) *{{comment}} As I identity as one of those people that think stubs should if not be left alone be set to a very low priority on stuff that needs to be "undone"... Not all stubs, even as empty as this, have the same value and as Webaware states it has been abandoned since Feb 2007, I wouldn't mind deleting it, but lets think about things clearly, what is the real point on losing time on this task (vfd of stubs), if they seem logical or at least look that some effort/time has gone into creating them leave them alone or just add some content to them, that is what I do to stubs I detect (if I have the time to do so). If there is a collision on subject mark it for merge. It seems that the reason for tagging stubs for vfd is that one is unsure that deletion is a valid option in the first place and policy seems to indicate they shouldn't (we probably should discuss that in place of rehashing the subject every time a stub is tagged). Last time I checked there were lots of stuff to do, in my to list the next thing (not on active status) is to spend some time in on the works needing merging... That said I will not participate in any more vfds on stubs and will by default support any undelete request made on them. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 04:57, 3 February 2008 (UTC) ::I quite like this approach (as I see it). Allow rather easier deletion of "stubs" but have a default of yes to undeleting if any reasonable request comes along from someone wanting to work on them (assuming that is not that different to your view Panic?) --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 07:59, 3 February 2008 (UTC) :::The problem of making this a rule of thumb is that it would prove to be detrimental to Wikibooks, by default a deletion in any form is an action against its creator. I was not proposing that. I was expressing that it would be a solution to prevent me engaging the same topic over and over to make people realize that stubs by "policy" should be left alone until they become an annoyance. :::The reason that the generalization of my new stance would not work is that after deletion only the creators would know that something was missing and what it was, they would be "lost" to the community. The usefulness of stubs is just that they provoke people into action since no one likes stubs in the first place, it saddens me that in place of contributing content people do chose the easy way out of the problem, by removing them. :::Stubs have other advantages, as examples; they may clarify the topic or propose avenues for extending a particular subject, they even serve to identify Wikibookians willing to contribute to it... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:26, 3 February 2008 (UTC) ::::Point taken to a degree at least. I have no objection to a "home" for stubs that may be used by someone sometime in the future (as sub pages of [[Inactive book stubs]] or whatever). However these "less than bare bones" of books may not be a good advertisement for some of the real quality books we do have. Make them findable but not top level? --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 12:18, 4 February 2008 (UTC) ::G'day Panic2k4, basically I'm finding these as I'm working through a bunch of pages looking for simple mistakes I can clean up when my brain can't cope with the work I'm meant to be doing. If it was capable of more complex tasks, it would be doing those (elsewhere), not gazing at Wikibooks. However, I'll make it clear on future listings of this nature that it can be assumed that you've voted in support of deleting them :-) [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 13:45, 3 February 2008 (UTC) :::You could do the reverse and state that I voted for keep, but that would open another can of worms, should we allow delegation of votes, I see it as a problematic enterprise... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:26, 3 February 2008 (UTC) ::::Maybe you should just !vote on any VFDs you care to, Panic.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 16:56, 4 February 2008 (UTC) :[[Image:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Speedy delete''' - [[WB:SPEEDY|no meaningful content]].  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 17:49, 4 February 2008 (UTC) ::I'm with Mike here. --- [[User:Anonymous Dissident|Anonymous Dissident]][[User_talk:Anonymous Dissident|Talk]] 11:54, 8 February 2008 (UTC) :{{del}} No content. Been a year without any updates. Member creating page is not active. [[User:ChessCreator|ChessCreator]] ([[User talk:ChessCreator|talk]]) 01:24, 12 February 2008 (UTC) |}

{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. [[:Image:Blender see.png]] and other files you uploaded may soon be deleted unless we can determine the copyright holder and status. The copyright holder is usually the creator, the creator's employer, or the last person who was transferred ownership rights. Please take the time to read [[Wikibooks:Media]] to learn more about what copyright information is required to satisfy our requirements and remember to include this important information for every file that you upload in the future as well. Please edit image descriptions pages directly to add this information; there's no need to upload the image again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask another Wikibookian at the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|help desk]]. See {{UserImages}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 16:54, 15 February 2008 (UTC)}} :If you're the creator of this image, then you must upload it under a free license. A fair use claim for self-made media is invalid. Please see [[WB:MEDIA]] for details, or ask on my talk page.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 16:56, 15 February 2008 (UTC)
